report_title: Campgrounds & RV Parks in the US
executive_summary: Rising disposable incomes will mitigate volatile oil prices to encourage road trips to campsites and RV parks over the next five years. Younger consumers' growing interest in camping and RV travel will fuel occupancy rates at campsites and RV parks. To attract campers with a larger budget, park owners will continue to offer more luxurious facilities and amenities to stave off competition from hotels and rental properties.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Changed the Way People Camp
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Work-from-home policies established during the pandemic increased the average consumer's leisure time and geographic flexibility. Cabin fever drove workers to seek a change of scenery and camping offered a safe way. Greater travel flexibility led to many new campers in 2020 and 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Campgrounds and RV Parks Get Younger and Change With the Ages
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The profile of the new camper is younger. Before, more than half of new campers used to be Millennials, but that share dropped to one-third as Gen Z's share grew to more than one-third. Camping amateurs are more likely to demand luxuries like wireless internet, pools and updated bathroom facilities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Peer-to-Peer Rentals Make Camping More Accessible
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rented camping equipment or RVs have become more popular amid the emergence of peer-to-peer rental sites. Rentals enable consumers who are financially strapped or don't want to commit to purchasing equipment to camp or to try a new camping experience.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Disposable Income and Consumer Confidence Dictate Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: For most campers, camping is a discretionary activity for leisure time. In tougher times, many consumers will cut back on camping trips, recreational vehicle purchases, or rentals.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Global oil prices are expected to fall over the next five years but with volatility. Consumers who avoid road trips because of lofty gas prices will be encouraged to take more trips during reduced-price periods. However, the prices of substitutes (hotels, restaurants) factor into the decision.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Younger Generations and New Groups Drive Growth in Camping
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the Kampgrounds of America's 2023 camping report, one-third of all campers were between 18 and 25 years of age (Gen Z) and a burgeoning group of more diverse guests and more representation of urban residents.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Camping Will Get Cozier as Disposable Incomes Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A growing economy will entice consumers to spend more on luxurious vacations, intensifying competition from hotels and rental properties. Campsite operators will likely build glamorous facilities and amenities to combat competition and sustain profit.

As technologies, including artificial intelligence, virtual reality technology and computers in general, continue to develop and become more advanced, campgrounds and RV parks will continue to face competition from other forms of entertainment that eat up discretionary income.

industry_definition: This industry operates recreational vehicle (RV) parks, campgrounds, and recreational and vacation camps. The industry also includes trailer and caravan parks and wilderness camps. Industry establishments cater to

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - increasing

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Zoning permits curb market concentration in the campground sector. They're often costly and time-consuming for newcomers, limiting the size of potential sites and adding to initial expenses.
Demand is surging for land near national parks. New park operators are capitalizing on this by developing luxury campsites in less traveled areas.

Campgrounds are upscaling due to a wealthier client base and competition from online rentals. To compete with luxurious accommodation sites, these outdoor lodgings are improving their facilities to attract the affluent camping market.

Rising income is pushing consumers to camp more. This rise will benefit city dwellers seeking respite at campsites, and peer-to-peer rental sites, which make camping accessible to novices by offering equipment and RV rentals.
Equity Lifestyle Properties dominates with over 5% of the national campground market.
RV park and campground owners thrive in related businesses. This gives them more customers, letting them efficiently offer various services.
Travel surged at RV parks and campsites post-pandemic. Years of enforced isolation boosted pent-up demand, with millions seeking outdoor leisure at campgrounds.
Prospective park owners have several funding avenues.
Prime campsite locations cost more, pushing developers into remote areas.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Generation Z includes consumers born between 1997 and 2012. Camping has become more popular among younger consumers with less disposable income than their older counterparts. Consumers aged 25 and younger are rediscovering the outdoors despite being digital natives, having grown up in a post-internet era.

Millennials are adults born between 1981 and 1996. 41.0% of new campers in 2021 were Millennials, according to Kampgrounds of America (KOA). As consumers in this age group become more established in their careers and earn higher incomes, they travel greater distances and stay in more upscale campsites. Work-from-home policies caused by the pandemic have encouraged millennials to travel more often. Campsites that offer wireless internet access perform better with this age group.

Generation X includes adults born between 1965 and 1980. This age cohort typically has consumers at the peak of their careers, encouraging them to swap out low-cost campsites for more upscale and comfortable hotels. Campsites and RV parks with luxurious amenities have the best chances of drawing in Gen X consumers.

Baby Boomers include those born between 1946 and 1964. RV ownership is becoming more popular among younger consumers, pushing out Baby Boomers. Demand from this segment is the weakest, as many individuals in this age group reside in assisted living facilities. Many also face health issues that restrict their ability to visit campgrounds and RV parks.

products_and_services.product_description: Overnight Recreational Camps are a Stable Summer Activity. Overnight recreational camps include sales from campground memberships, tuitions and long-term fees. Typical monthly rates at an RV park or campground range between $300.00 and $500.00. Nearly half of all industry sales come from memberships and fees. Fees vary between campsites and depend on the number of amenities available. Rising disposable income has boosted business for overnight recreational camps in recent years.

Peer-to-Peer Rental Sites Drive Consumers to RV Parks and Campgrounds. This segment includes RV parks and short-term campgrounds. RVs combine transportation and temporary living quarters, providing a more comfortable but low-cost travel experience. RV usage is soaring among younger

products_and_services.product_or_service: Other Unit Accommodations and Service Fees
products_and_services.product_description: Food and Nonalcoholic Beverage Sales Rise Alongside Occupancy Rates. All other products and services include the sale of food and beverages and telecommunication services. Food and beverage sales at campgrounds and RV parks depend entirely on occupancy rates, which increase alongside broader economic growth and camping trends.

tier_1_suppliers: Vending Machine Operators in the US
Water & Sewer Line Construction in the US
Transmission Line Construction in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Heavy Equipment Rental in the US
Tool & Equipment Rental in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Domestic trips by US residents include all forms of travel, including RV travel. Demand for campgrounds and RV parks grows when US residents make more domestic trips. Domestic travel aligns with the overall economy, as greater disposable income levels permit consumers to spend more on trips.

Sales and shipments of RVs indicate demand for RV spaces in campgrounds and RV parks. When sales and shipments of RVs increase, RV travel activity expands. As consumers travel the country with RVs, RV parks gain more business.

Changes in consumers' disposable income levels significantly influence the amount that people travel. Given that travel is classified as a discretionary form of spending, individuals tend to travel more when disposable income levels are high. RV parks and campgrounds benefit from increased disposable income as it boosts the number of domestic trips and increases the chances that travelers will stop by these recreation sites.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of Adults Aged 50 and Older
demand_determinants.determinant_description: People aged 50 and older account for a significant share of the total demand for campgrounds and RV parks. Older adults have more leisure time as they are more likely to be retired. This age group is more likely to camp in an RV than their younger counterparts.

Industry performance is closely tied to the price of crude oil since most automobiles, including recreation vehicles, are fueled by gas. When crude oil prices rise, gas prices rise, hindering consumers' willingness to take long road trips, while a decrease in crude oil prices will encourage travel in cars and RVs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Time Spent on Leisure and Sports
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Camping is affected by consumers' time spent on leisure and sports. When time spent on leisure activities increases, camping trips rally, boosting demand for industry services. When time spent on leisure activities declines, camping trips fall, leading to lower demand for industry services.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast's dense population, accounting for over a quarter of the US, provides a broad local market for campgrounds and RV parks. This concentrated population allows these businesses to thrive. Many potential campers prefer not to venture too far for a close-to-home adventure, thus giving rise to the demand for campsites and RV parks within this region. Florida, with its warm climate and unique landscape featuring native palm trees, serves as a popular destination not only for local Southeast residents but also for travelers from other states.

Campgrounds and RV parks in the West are near significant tourist attractions such as national parks, lakes, and mountains. These regions comprise 24 of the nation's 63 national parks, making the West a sought-after destination for travelers. California, Nevada, and Hawaii's year-round warm climate draws tourists even in winter, increasing the appeal for campground and RV park enterprises. This constant influx of visitors allows for consistent revenue and protects these businesses from seasonal swings, making it an ideal spot for campers searching for favorable weather.

The Great Lakes region, with over 9,400 miles of coastline, is abundant in campgrounds and RV parks. This abundance outpaces the region's population share, suggesting that the appeal for camping and RV destinations outweighs the need for residential spaces. This surplus of camping locations is attributed to the region's unique offering. Access to watersports, diverse wildlife, historical landmarks, and other tourist attractions make it a magnetic destination for camping enthusiasts.

The Mid-Atlantic region captivates with its natural beauty, offering varied outdoor experiences in coastal, forest, and mountain settings. As seasons change, these landscapes transform, presenting an evolving scenic appeal. For adventurers, this constant allure is a driving factor in this region's continued patronage of campgrounds and RV parks. This region isn't just about natural beauty. Its rich historical significance, exemplified through numerous monuments, museums and historical towns, further attracts tourists. The region's proximity to major urban centers such as New York City, Philadelphia, and Washington DC also makes it a strategic location for campground and RV park businesses. Being near such bustling metropolises provides business opportunities and an exciting juxtaposition of city and nature to any traveler's itinerary.

regulations_points.regulation_title: PATIENT PROTECTION AFFORDABLE CARE ACT (PPACA) AND FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE PROTECT WORKERS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The PPACA requires campsites and RV parks with 50 or more employees who work more than 30 hours a week to provide healthcare benefits. Most campgrounds and parks employ fewer than 50 workers and are not subject to the PPACA. Campgrounds and RV parks must pay workers no less than the federal minimum wage, although each state formulates and regulates its own minimum wage.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FDA, EPA, DEPARTMENTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND ZONING PROTECT CONSUMERS AND RESIDENTS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA (Food and Drug Administration) establishes rules and standards for food handling and presentation. State and local health departments have regulations concerning sanitation, food preparation and services and facilities guidelines. The EPA can regulate "public water systems," while Departments of Environmental Protection have policies concerning water usage, cleanliness, pollution and wildlife protection. Various state and local regulations handle building and zoning permits.
Many states issued regulations and restrictions on travel amid COVID-19. Some states required incoming travelers to quarantine for two weeks at the beginning of the pandemic.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Launching a new campground or RV park involves navigating complex legal requirements such as securing zoning and building permits from local authorities which may deter potential operators.
Considerable capital investment is needed to kick off a new campground or RV park operation, typically for land acquisition and developing desirable facilities to be competitive.
Standing out in the competitive campground and RV park industry is difficult. Location and amenities play a critical role, and acquiring a prime location or providing upscale amenities can be costly.
Continued investment is essential for maintaining a campground's competitiveness, as facilities upkeep and luxurious amenities require substantial ongoing capital expenditure.

basis_points.basis_title: Scenic Space is Limited and Hard to Come By
basis_points.basis_description: There are a fixed number of national parks in the US, most of which have established campsites within their borders or nearby. Potential campsite operators need significant capital to purchase these existing campgrounds. Also, unused land in high-demand areas comes at a cost.

basis_points.basis_title: Seasonality and Interest Rates Benefit Larger Firms
basis_points.basis_description: Fixed costs associated with maintaining facilities and amenities exist even when business is slow in the off-season. This puts greater pressure on smaller firms and gives advantages to larger firms that are better able to stash profit and revenue during peak season.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Zoning permits curb market concentration in the campground sector. They're often costly and time-consuming for newcomers, limiting the size of potential sites and adding to initial expenses.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Demand for land near national parks
concentration_points.concentration_description: Demand is surging for land near national parks. New park operators are capitalizing on this by developing luxury campsites in less traveled areas.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Low Rent Costs Accompany High Depreciation Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Most campground and RV park operators own the land and facilities, with rent costs virtually nonexistent. While permit fees are not recorded as rent costs, they vary depending on location but generally present a significant upfront cost. Taxes and interest payments are additional and recurring costs. Owned facilities and amenities have significant wear and tear, which hikes up depreciation costs. Additionally, these costs are present even during off-seasons when business is slow.

Despite the moderate capital costs campground operators incur, labor is essential to running a successful site. Employees are required to manage, clean, take reservations and handle other operational tasks. Employees aid guests and are responsible for cleaning and maintaining on-site facilities. Due to this reason, labor costs account for the highest revenue share.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Continued investment is essential for maintaining a campground's competitiveness in a market with rising consumer expectations. Facilities upkeep, especially for more luxurious add-ons such as tennis courts or fitness centers, requires substantial ongoing capital expenditure.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 CHANGED THE WAY PEOPLE CAMP
volatility_points.volatility_description: Increased leisure time, thanks to flexible work-from-home policies, life changes spurred by the pandemic (such as moving, buying or selling personal property) and the suspension of social activities, pushed many consumers to take up glamping and overlanding in 2020. Consumers often use online accommodation providers to book glamping stays and overlanding is an autonomous form of camping. Both drive businesses away from RV parks and campsites.

volatility_points.volatility_title: REVENGE TRAVEL WAS A BOON FOR CAMPSITES AND RV PARKS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Domestic trips by US residents soared in 2021 amid a widespread vaccine rollout and reduced pandemic restrictions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: CAMPSITES UPGRADE AMENITIES TO SATISFY DEMAND FOR GLAMOROUS CAMPING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Glamping (glam camping) is a rising trend among younger campers who want to experience the outdoors comfortably. Providing upscale facilities and luxurious amenities is essential to capturing new markets. Upscale facilities like pools, gyms and scenic yoga studios can create a luxury campsite experience and stave off competition from more optimally located camps and parks.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales affected by seasonality?
FAQs.answer: In some parts of the country, seasonality does affect industry operations and revenue. Usually, during the summer, demand is the highest.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage social media platforms like Facebook or Twitter to inform and attract new customers? Is your company also present on review sites?
FAQs.answer: Operators have increasingly started to focus on social media platforms to market their sites. Companies can also expand their reach and attract more customers by having high ratings on review websites, such as Yelp.

FAQs.question: Do you offer ancillary services to diversify revenue streams?
FAQs.answer: Ancillary and value-add services such as glamping have increased over the past five years. Added services can increase demand as they can attract a wider range of customers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities to expand your market share?
FAQs.answer: Larger players have grown immensely over the past five years by constantly acquiring new sites. By increasing presence in the same area as existing campgrounds or expanding to other regions, companies can accommodate more customers.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer web-based booking to improve consumer accessibility?
FAQs.answer: Services such as online reservations are now available. Online reservation services can increase accessibility for customers as well as ease customer planning processes.

FAQs.question: Does your establishment offer complimentary Wi-Fi to customers?
FAQs.answer: Wi-Fi services have become increasingly common on camp sites, attracting millennials.

FAQs.question: As ancillary services have expanded at industry establishments, what measures does your company take to ensure all employees are compliant with food handling and safety laws?
FAQs.answer: Compliance costs have remained steady over the past five years. Complying with food safety laws is increasingly pertinent as companies offer additional services, such as offering food services to customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company compliant with the varying labor regulations across states?
FAQs.answer: Companies have to follow local, federal and state regulations.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'? What are your company's primary expenses?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins are much higher for larger operators than single-campsite owners.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to make sure debt-management processes are efficient? Are there any ongoing financing challenges your company is contending with?
FAQs.answer: Managing debt levels is critical for REITs as dividend payments are constant and higher dividend yields attract more investors to the company.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients were referred to you by another satisfied customer? What is your reputation like among consumers?
FAQs.answer: Companies benefit from good word-of-mouth recommendations, which will generate new and repeat visitors. In addition, companies can benefit from recommendations on review sites, such as Yelp.

FAQs.question: Considering the industry's seasonal nature, how do you attract and retain a skilled workforce? What qualifications are required of your staff?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs in this industry tend to be high, relative to other industries. Companies can gain a competitive advantage and drive down costs by employing a skilled but temporary workforce.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your facilities are located in an optimal location? How do you prepare for volatility in the weather?
FAQs.answer: Successful industry participants take advantage of their geographic location, whether this is proximity to national parks or areas of favorable weather. However, some regions provide for more seasonal demand than others.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? Have you experienced declines in demand for your services when the dollar appreciates?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its trading partners. A strong US dollar encourages domestic travelers to take trips abroad rather than use industry services, because traveling becomes more affordable.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from adults 50 and over? What services do you target specifically to this cohort?
FAQs.answer: People aged 50 and older account for a majority of total demand for RV parks. This age segment's share of the population is expected to rise with the progressive aging of the baby-boomer population in the near future. However, millennials have increasingly taken interest in RVs and camping in recent years, indicating a growing market within younger age groups.

FAQs.question: How have recent trends in domestic trips by US residents affected your revenue and profit? How do you attract domestic travelers to your locations?
FAQs.answer: Domestic trips by US residents include all forms of travel, including RV travel. Demand for campgrounds and RV parks typically improves when the number of domestic trips by US residents rises.
